title: Storage-Attached Indexing
description:
This is a brief demo to highlight Datastax's new feature, Storage-Attached Indexes, available in DSE and AstraDB.

REPO FOR THE DEMO:
https://github.com/DataStax-Examples/sai-demo

LOTS OF SAMPLES:
https://github.com/DataStax-Examples

CONNECT WITH DATASTAX
Subscribe: http://www.youtube.com/c/datastaxdevs?sub_confirmation=1 
Twitter: https://twitter.com/datastaxdevs
Twitch: https://www.twitch.tv/datastaxdevs

ABOUT DATASTAX DEVELOPERS
On the DataStax Developers YouTube channel, you can find tutorials, workshops and much more to help you learn and stay updated with the latest information on Apache CassandraÂ©.  Create an account on https://academy.datastax.com to watch our free online courses, tutorials, and more.

transcript.text: and now i'm going to start the cql shell and let's take a look so first let's look at the information that we have so we have the recipient id recipient account time create time data sender id and size and again if we wanted to if we wanted to find out for example all of the emails that were sent before 2020 we would find out that this query would error out and so what what we'll do is we'll just create we'll create that index on this field and now if we run this query again we can see that this is actually a this is actually doing a a search and comparing comparing the the different dates so we can also we can also see how many uh how many there were and you will get this warning of if you use an aggregation query without the partition key this um this is not something that you should do without that partition key but this again as we're exploring the data as we're getting to know the table that we have this shows us this shows us more information about about our table next if i wanted to look up information or data by account type i could create i could create an index on account type and account type if we remember if we remember is actually part of the partition key so this is really cool this means that you can now you can now select information and find information even when you only have part of the partition key without the storage attached index again you would need to have the full partition key in order to in order to access that information and then just to show as well we can also run comparisons on numbers so if we create an index on size we can then find all of the the emails between between a given size and and see that see that below and so if we take a look for example if we turn if we turn on tracing we'll do that just with tracing on if we run this same query what we'll see i mean we'll see a lot of information and we'll see we'll see exactly where where the data is getting getting sent to so you can see that a range request has been sent to to all all nodes and is being processed across all nodes remember we just have just have these three nodes but they are all performing this lookup and and reading back reading back this information and then sending it sending it back to us [Music]
